did.abstract: Norris family of Ypsilanti and Grand Rapids, Michigan. Papers of Mark Norris, Ypsilanti businessman and postmaster; papers of his wife, Roccena Vaill Norris, local teacher and woman's rights advocate; papers of their son, Lyman, attorney and regent of the University of Michigan, 1883-1884; papers of Lyman's son, Mark Norris, Grand Rapids attorney and Grand Master of the Knights Templar in the United States; papers of Lyman's daughter Maria Norris, Grand Rapids physician; papers of Mark's son, Abbott Norris; and related papers of other family members, notably the Whittelsey family of Connecticut.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The collection was donated by Margaret Abbott Norris (donor no. 3927) in 1962. Additional materials were transferred from the Graduate Library of the University of Michigan (donor no. 1278)

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

userestrict.p: Copyright has not been transferred to the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: item, folder title, box no., Norris Family Papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: The papers of the Norris family cover four generations, 1815-1960, in the lives of an Ypsilanti and Grand Rapids family. The first member of the family represented in the papers is Mark Norris (1796-1862). Mark Norris was born in Vermont, but by 1820 he was a businessman and postmaster in Covington, New York where he married Roccena B. Vaill (1797-1876). She was the daughter of James and Helen Compton Vaill and taught school in Covington. Mark and Roccena had two children, Elvira (b. 1821), who married Benjamin Follett in 1841; and Lyman Decatur (1823-1894).

Around 1828, largely because of anti-Masonic sentiment, the Norrises moved to the Ypsilanti, Michigan area. Roccena taught school briefly and Mark worked as postmaster while conducting other business interests. When his health failed in the late 1850's, the Norrises' son, Lyman Decatur, took over the family's business affairs.

Lyman D. Norris studied at Marshall College from 1839-1841. He then became the first student to matriculate at the University of Michigan in the fall of 1841. He studied further at Yale from 1844-1845 and graduated in 1845 with degrees from both universities.

Norris read law in Detroit with Alexander Fraser, was admitted to the bar in 1847, and began his practice in St. Louis, Missouri the following year. During the early 1850's he studied and traveled in Europe. In 1852, Norris participated on the state level in the Dred Scott slavery case as counsel for Scott's owner, Dr. John Emerson. Throughout his career in St. Louis, Norris was involved in local Democratic politics. Lyman D. Norris practiced law in Ypsilanti from 1854-1871 and then in Grand Rapids from 1871 until his death in 1894. In his later years he was fairly active in state Democratic politics and University of Michigan affairs, being appointed a regent in 1883.

Lyman D. Norris married Lucy Alsop Whittelsey of Middletown, Connecticut in 1854. They had two living children: Mark Norris (1857-1943) and Maria W. Norris (ca. 1858-1938). The son, Mark Norris studied at the University of Michigan and graduated from the law school in 1882. He practiced law with his father, Lyman D. Norris, for several years in Grand Rapids, and was very active in the Masonic Order being elected Grand Master in 1937. His son, Abbott L. Norris carried on the family law offices. Maria W. Norris was educated in Montreal and Boston. She studied medicine and later became a prominent Grand Rapids physician.

scopecontent.p: The Norris family papers consists of three linear feet of correspondence, business papers, and scrapbooks. The bulk of the papers are letters among various family members which contain a wealth of information about 19th century daily life, social conditions, business affairs, and local and state politics. This collection is especially useful in researching: women's history; Norris family and kinship interrelationships; early area settlement and local history; university student life at the University of Michigan and elsewhere; 19th century economic conditions and political issues; and 20th century Freemasonry.

scopecontent.p: The papers of Mark Norris cover the period 1825-1859 and consist of business papers and correspondence regarding banking, milling and railroads, and some letters with his wife Roccena, brother-in-law Benjamin Vaill and son-in-law Benjamin Follett. Included are a long series of letters from the Norrises' son, Lyman Decatur, concerning his student days at Marshall, the University of Michigan and Yale, 1831-1845; his subsequent travels through Europe, 1850-1851; and his legal career, including a letter, March 31, 1852, about the Dred Scott case.

did.unittitle: Papers (including business correspondence and related materials)

odd.p: include warranty deeds and land agreements for Norris properties

did.unittitle: Letters (to and from wife Roccena B. Vaill Norris)
Letters (to and from son Lyman Decatur Norris addressed to both parents)
Roccena B. (Vaill) Norris (1797-1876), wife of Mark Norris

scopecontent.p: The papers of Roccena B. Vaill Norris cover 1825-1876 and consist mainly of letters with friends and early feminist leaders. There is also correspondence with daughter Elvira Norris Follett and son Lyman Decatur, and letters with other relatives including her sister Lucinda, brother-in-law George Knapp and Civil War letters from nephew Andrew Knapp.

Throughout her life Roccena Norris was active in a variety of literary and charitable pursuits. She was also greatly interested in women's rights, especially with higher education for women and the suffrage movement. In this regard, she corresponded frequently with early feminists Caroline Kirkland and Electa M. Sheldon (later Electa Stewart), among others. Roccena Norris also did mission work through the Presbyterian Church and the local Ladies Home Association of which she was president for over sixteen years. In addition, she helped found the Ladies Library Association in 1868 and was one of its strongest supporters.

did.unittitle: Letters with daughter, Elvira Norris Follett 1836-1842
Letters with son, Lyman Decatur Norris
Lyman Decatur Norris (1823-1894), son of Mark and Roccena, Norris

scopecontent.p: The papers of Lyman Decatur Norris span the years 1837-1891 and consist of some business and legal correspondence regarding 1870's politics and University of Michigan regental matters. Among his personal correspondence are letters with his wife, Lucy Whittelsey Norris, mainly concerning family matters and daily life; letters from their children, Mark and Maria; and correspondence with other friends and relatives, including sister, Elvira N. Follett.

did.unittitle: Papers (including business and political correspondence and related financial materials)
Letters with sister and brother-in-law, Elvira N. and Ben Follett
Letters with wife, Lucy A. (Whittelsey) Norris
Letters with children, Mark and Maria
Miscellaneous papers, fragments, and newspaper clippings
Scrapbook concerning Civil War and post-war politics circa 1861-1886
Lucy A. (Whittelsey) Norris, wife of Lyman D. Norris

scopecontent.p: The papers of Lucy Whittelsey Norris cover 1862-1891 and consist of correspondence with her relatives and friends, including a separate series with her mother, Sarah Tracy Whittelsey 1869-1877; and with her children.

odd.p: (See also related Whittelsey material listed below)

did.unittitle: Letters with children, Mark and Maria
Miscellaneous correspondence and financial papers (undated and fragmentary)

scopecontent.p: Miscellaneous Norris family material, including notes, invitations and circulars.

did.unittitle: Whittelsey family (letters of parents and other relatives of Lucy A. Whittelsey Norris)

scopecontent.p: Additional Whittelsey family material, consisting of some letters of Lucy's parents, Chauncey and Sarah Whittelsey, and her brothers, Charles Chauncey of St. Louis and Eben, who died in the Civil War, August, 1862.

did.unittitle: Chauncey Whittelsey, father of Lucy Whittelsey Norris
Sarah T. Whittelsey, mother of Lucy Whittelsey Norris
Letters with son, Charles Chauncey Whittelsey
Letters with friends and relatives circa 1840-1888 (scattered dates)
Eben F. Whittelsey (d. 1862), brother of Lucy Whittelsey Norris

scopecontent.p: The papers of Mark Norris, son of Lyman D. and Lucy Norris, cover the years 1883-1942 and deal mostly with Freemasonry activities and his election as Grand Master in 1937.

did.unittitle: Legal papers and miscellaneous correspondence circa 1883-1937 (scattered dates)
Speeches, drafts and related materials (primarily of Freemasons)
Miscellaneous Freemason publications and related materials
Biographical material-by and about Mark Norris

scopecontent.p: The papers of Abbott Norris, son of Mark and Cornella Norris, cover the years 1936-1960 and consist of correspondence with members of Congress including Bartel Jonkman, Carl Mapes, Arthur Vandenberg and Burton Wheeler, among others, concerning taxes and pending legislation.

did.unittitle: Portraits of Lyman and Mark Norris, and group portrait of Alpha Delta Phi fraternity at the University of Michigan circa 1879
